"The girl who narrates ths show asks the children questions about
the previous show and gives the children a chance to answer and to think
for themselves. She creates excellent word-pictures by malting the most
of word sounds be it "squishy," "slushy,” "puddle," or "Stopi " She uses
a lot of poetry| and most of it is there and gone without being obvious
which to mind is the way poetry should be presented. Even some of her
stories utilize lots of rhyme and rhythm.
"Her explanations are simple, yet very effective—she has for example^
a beautiful explanation of an island, which any small child can understand.
In some things, the Xistemer can actually par -iclpate—simple action®
that don8t require much material, maybe pencil and paper or merely the rug
on the floor* When she says, "Let5s pretend this or that,..1*, it is
very effective, because she is careful about using lots of detail to
build up pictures.
"Her use of music and sound is extremely effective, too. There is a
nice amont of music that is highly descriptive, i„e. , a rippling piano
pieco for water; some wonderful "walking" music. Much of the music ia

show* **
